reviews.title: Wow, what a missed opportunity!
text: Wow, what a disappointment!  It's just one miss after another along this waterfront. Boring ugly apartment buildings la king any landscaping, leading up to Rogers arena which has got to (be at least on the outside)one of the ugliest baseball stadiums in North America. And then you have the CN Tower which is also just hideous in a painfully brutalist way. And then of course on top of that you have a massive power station.  Boring chain restaurants with zero charm.  They just missed at every turn.

It looks to me like this was done in the '60s and is definitely a need of a redevelopment. You can see efforts are being made here and there with new restaurants going in, but really it needs a massive redevelopment overhaul. We are from Vancouver and we're expecting something along the lines of the charming Vancouver waterfront near the convention center, or maybe the shipyards near North Vancouver which had an excellent redevelopment and is now a wonderful place to hang out. This is not bad. Long long way to go here.

reviews.title: Great views
text: Lovely walk along the waterfont with great views of the Islands & boats with plenty of places for refreshment along the way.

reviews.title: Peaceful
text: The Toronto Waterfront is a great place to enjoy beautiful scenery of lake Ontario. Access is provided via public transportation.

reviews.title: Still beautiful despite the rain
text: It poured rain the two days we were in the area. It definitely wasn’t ideal but we tried hard to still enjoy. The location itself is great and the waterfront is pretty fun! I bet the summers are awesome.

reviews.title: Not going back
text: We expected a busy waterfront area with shops and restaurants. What we found was just a shaded area along the waterfront. Nice but not what we expected. We were disappointed.

reviews.title: One of the more distinctive parts of the city
text: The waterfront is one of the nicer parts of the city, and especially of the downtown core, but not one that gets as much attention as other, less interesting areas.  Definitely worth a look for someone already in the centre.

reviews.title: Nice place for a tranquilizing experience
text: The place is very well designed with separate tracks for vehicles, trams bicycles and pedestrians. If you plan walking , get down at Harbourfront center and walk towards Billy Bishop Airport along the Ontario Lake. The cool breeze would calm you down. An array of restaurants serving multiple cuisines to pamper your palate are available as well. You can take kayak as well from the Kayaking Center and get to go to the lake by yourself as well.

reviews.title: Great walking
text: Very nice walking along the Toronto waterfront. Nice water views and nice city views. Lots of places to take a break. Nice wetland area and nice garden area with monarch butterflies.

reviews.title: Lovey place to be at.
text: It’s a lovely place to take a stroll along the water front with plenty of cafes or bars for you to stop at along the way.

reviews.title: Great area
text: The area along the lake looks great on a sunny summer day.  The ballpark is there. And the tower.  And the aquarium and lots of places to eat.  I’d like to go back again some time.

reviews.title: A good morning walk
text: Toronto’s waterfront is gorgeous and clean There are a lot of residential areas by the water.Walking around meant interacting with the locals as they go about their daily life.I like that when I travel.

reviews.title: Vibrant
text: I walk along the waterfront regularly and love the vibrancy of the visitors as well as the craft vendors and buskers. The open air stages are great to visit, too, with free music and dance. It's a shame that so many condos and commercial buildings are being built along the waterfront, but nonetheless, it's my favourite place to chill.

reviews.title: Watched the air show
text: We went and sat upon a hill to watch the air show on Sunday. Then part way through we decided to walk down towards the lake front & saw that they had little shops in shipping containers & food trucks. It was a beautiful day till the rain hit. But we had a great time & took lots of pictures!

reviews.title: Loved it
text: Love Toronto. Beautiful city, with an architecture and a vibe that resembles Sidney in a way ... !!
Waterfront is beautiful and it's worth a nice walk on a sunny day !!
We started from Union Station to the Bay Area and then we walked on the Waterfront. It was game day, so Toronto Blue Jays were playing ... the stadium area was packed !!
It was a nice experience !

reviews.title: Contains a lot of interesting activities
text: The Waterfront is a key place to visit in Toronto. There is access to the ferries taking you out to the islands, the CN Tower and the Blue Jay's Rogers Centre. There is also the beginning of Yonge Street.

reviews.title: Nice to stroll along the water...
text: We walked along the waterfront, and it made for a pleasant morning. There were lots of boats going in and out, many people out for a walk, and lots of cafes and restaurants. Note that it may be a little cooler and breezy down by the lake, so you might want a jacket, even in summer. Parking in the area is a little pricey, but gets much cheaper if you go a little west & north (we parked on Blue Jays Way, north of Front St), and are willing to walk just a little.

reviews.title: A wonderful stop in the city
text: We were lucky enough to arrive during the Canada 150th celebration. With the six story yellow rubber duck on location and a wonderful waterfront fest taking place, the area was packed with tourists and locals alike. The area is robust with historic monuments to firemen, and the seaport itself is an exciting and well designed area.

reviews.title: Redpath Waterfront Festival
text: I came here to check out the massive Rubber Ducky at the Redpath Waterfront Festival on Canada Day weekend. It was PACKED with people! A little crazy due to the crowds but a lot of fun! Continued walking east all the way to Sugar Beach...

reviews.title: Definitely worth a look!
text: We went for a ride and a walk along the waterfront while we were staying in Toronto.
It was really warm while we were there and the place was bustling. Great way to spend an hour while you're in town.

reviews.title: Everyone should check it out.
text: I think the waterfront in Toronto is one of the best places to go for a walk or bicycle.  The boardwalks, sights, cafes are all places one should check out when visiting Toronto. The water is fairly clean to look at, lots of history along the waterfront and you can walk for ages. Lost of parks and places to sit.  The area is a must do when in Toronto.  Some beautiful nature sites, some older building and factory like areas. Good foot paths. A good way to explore the city from the south if you have the time and transportation to do it.

reviews.title: Wonderful
text: A very pleasant way to spend a few hours on a warm and sunny day.  Bars/restaurants if you’re in need of refreshment and there are many benches providing rest from the sun’s strong rays.  A short ride to the Toronto Islands is well worth the price of admission.

reviews.title: Nice Walk
text: Make sure you take a walk along the waterfront in Toronto. It's a nice view across to the islands and you can see plenty of things. There are lots of boats to see including the water taxis who will take you across to the island at $10 per head.
There's also shops and cafes, bars restaurants so you can sit and have a rest if you need it.
The street cars also run along part of the front as well for those of you who can't walk too far.

reviews.title: Cycling on the waterfront - Martin Goodman
text: The Martin Goodman Trail is a nicely paved path that has room for walkers, cyclists and any other moving sport.  It’s been well maintained since built and I ride it weekly   A great place to ride with friends.

reviews.title: Pleasant enough
text: There are enough bars and restaurants in this area to make a stroll and a little people watching worth your while and it's also an area from which it's possible boat for an island trip. That said the biggest difficulty we faced was in actually getting to the waterfront - less than straightforward .... for me at least - so take your time and a map ! OR check it out first from the top of the CN Tower - lol ... as we did !

reviews.title: Nice run or a walk. Lavazza coffee!
text: I was jogging in the morning from downtown area all the way to the city airport. Nice waterfront. Later in the afternoon we had a nice walk with friends enjoying the waterfront views. They have a Lavazza coffee shop there, in case you miss good coffee during your trip :)

reviews.title: Sunny waterfornt
text: Plenty of boat trips around the harbour and to the islands - a few nice restaurants and bars and not much else to do other than sit and enjoy the views. Pleasant way to spend an hour or so.

reviews.title: Relaxing
text: I would recommend heading over there if you are nearby and want a nice place to relax, if there is a concert/performance, or if you rent a bike.

I wish you can walk by the water for a long stretch but the Toronto Music Garden, HTO park, Harbourfront Centre, Harbour Square Park, Sugar Beach/Sherbourne Commons are along Queens Quay West. You would need to walk back on to the street to walk to the next area if you want to see them all.
I do see how it is a nice relaxing area for locals with a pleasant view.

reviews.title: Pleasant evening stroll
text: On a warm summers evening and after a cruise around the harbour this was a very pleasant stroll.  I felt safe walking along the waterfront and found a number of options for snacks and drinks.  Accessible by public transport and with several quality hotels for those who are looking to stay close to downtown.

reviews.title: Missed opportunity
text: So much potential--blocked by bad planning. The waterfront has been built and added onto hodge lodge over the decades and there are nice little bits and pieces but very unfortunately, owing to the wall of condos put up in the 90s and subsequent mediocrity, it's mostly a disjointed mess. Your best bet is to line up at the Soviet-style ferry terminal tucked behind, you guessed it--a condo--and go out to the island. The city also charges richly for this privileged 8 minute ride but you get nice walks and beaches and views once you're out there. The other choice is Leslie Spit on the weekends, which is free and has million dollar views but no beaches.

reviews.title: Nice
text: Very nice to stroll along the waterfront. Close to the city center, many food and drink options available.

reviews.title: Always something to do
text: Toronto waterfront is a great place to visit especially in the summer. There is always tons to do with all the restaurants, bars, and many other retailers. Walking along the water or just having a coffee overlooking the lake is always great.

reviews.title: Birthday celbration--Toronto Waterfront
text: Last year in June my two sons ,myself and a father-in -law to one of my sons celebrated a birthday as both fathers have June birthday dates and we went to the waterfront and enjoyed a great lunch at the Amsterdam Brew House restaurant overlooking Lake Ontario.
We then took a trip on a Schooner that was parked on the waterfront and enjoyed the Toronto view from the ship
I highly recommend going to the Toronto waterfront as there is a lot to do and experience

reviews.title: Lovely Walking - Stunning Views
text: A walk along the waterfront is superb whatever the season you visit Toronto. It’s really relaxing and enjoyable. The views are breathtaking over the water.

reviews.title: Skating, museum, shops
text: Not a lot of waterfront that is easy to access,  but a bit to do. Some boats, some shops. Skating in winter is free.
If you don't skate likely an hour is enough,  in winter. Longer in summer.

reviews.title: Good Place for a Walk on a Sunny Day
text: Walking back to our condo from downtown, we chose to walk along the waterfront. It was a nice walk, but not exactly direct, due to the docks and buildings in the way.

reviews.title: Scotiabank Toronto Waterfront Marathon 2018
text: This was a well run race, from information, bib pickup, the exhibitions to the actual event - very organized.  The city and crowd was welcoming.  We lucked out with the weather and our friends and family enjoyed themselves.  The run was fantastic, mostly flat and easier to PR. The only thing I want to comment on was it was a little difficult to get to the expo.  I used the free shuttle which was a nice perk, but hard to locate and lots of traffic.  Thank you to all the volunteers!!! Would definitely do this run again.

reviews.title: what a beautful and quaint city
text: As a New Yorker and no stranger to metropolitan waterfronts I must say that Toronto's is one of the most magnificent. The area boasts so many diverse areas of interest. A square where you're only a few steps from the Ripley's aquarium, Rogers Center (where the MLB Blue Jays play) and the CN Tower.
What we loved even more are the oddities and landmarks that give a unique Toronto flavor to the area. Absolutely breathtaking and romantic!

reviews.title: Would be nice but very difficult to find path
text: I tried to walk along the waterfront a couple of times when in Toronto. I found it quite tricky to get a decent stretch of path, being blocked by ongoing development, condo car parks or hotel parking areas. I did manage to walk a short distance and it was very pleasant with great views onto the Lake and along the shore line.

reviews.title: Just a stroll around
text: We were at the Toronto Waterfront catching a ferry to the islands so we had a bit of time to stroll around and take in the views of the boats in the water, flowers in full bloom and looking behind at all the tall buildings of the city was relaxing. However, getting there and trying to find parking was rather stressful. There was construction, lots of traffic and poor signage in how to get to it. We relied on the car's GPS.

reviews.title: from Queen's Quay St., we were unable to find the actual waterfront due to lack of signs and patchwork development
text: We tried to walk along the waterfront but had a hard time actually accessing it. Walking along Queen's Quay St., we never saw a sign or clear path directing us to any parks or paths that actually fronted the water. All we found were some places to board water taxis plus parking lots, hotels, condos, plus a lot of ongoing construction which all blocked access to the actual waterfront. As a result of the lack of signs and all the blocking structures and ongoing construction which prevented access, am only giving 2 stars due to the difficulty of accessing the waterfront. If the waterfront is something the city wants tourists to be able to enjoy, the city should make it easy for tourists to actually be able to find it and not encounter obstacles wherever they looked. We looked for access all along Queen's Quay and never found it anywhere. Left very frustrated because we really wanted to enjoy the waterfront.
